# Tanger Med **Tanger Med** (Arabic: طنجة المتوسط, *Tanja al-Mutawassit*) is a Moroccan industrial and commercial port complex located in northern [Morocco](/article/en/Morocco), approximately 40–45 km northeast of [Tangier](/article/en/Tangier) on the [Strait of Gibraltar](/article/en/Strait_of_Gibraltar). Situated 14–15 km from the Spanish coast (opposite [Tarifa](/article/en/Tarifa,_Spain)), the port occupies a strategic position on major global maritime trade routes connecting [Asia](/article/en/Asia), [Europe](/article/en/Europe), and [North America](/article/en/North_America). As the largest port in [Africa](/article/en/Africa) and the [Mediterranean Sea](/article/en/Mediterranean_Sea), Tanger Med serves as a major transshipment hub and is ranked 19th globally among container ports. ## Overview Tanger Med is one of the largest industrial ports in the world, with a total container handling capacity of 11 million [Twenty-foot Equivalent Units](/article/en/Twenty-foot_equivalent_unit) (TEU). The port complex is designed to handle 7 million passengers annually, process 700,000 TIR trucks, export 1 million vehicles, and manage 15 million tons of hydrocarbons. The port is surrounded by a free trade zone hosting more than 1,300 companies representing an annual export business volume of approximately €14 billion as of 2023, operating across diverse sectors including [automotive](/article/en/Automotive_industry), [aerospace](/article/en/Aerospace), food processing, logistics, and textiles. The project constitutes a strategic priority of the Moroccan government for economic and social development in northern Morocco, oriented toward leveraging the nation's [free trade agreement](/article/en/Free_trade_agreement) with the [European Union](/article/en/European_Union). The particular geographic position at the crossing of two major maritime routes and the port's proximity to the EU market provide access to hundreds of millions of consumers. ## History ### Early Development (2003–2007) The Tanger Med project was initiated in 2003 through the creation of the Agence Spéciale Tanger Méditerranée (TMSA, later known as the Tanger Mediterranean Special Agency), a public limited company tasked with implementing, coordinating, and managing the port complex. Construction commenced in 2004 and progressed for approximately three years before the inaugural phase became operational. The first container terminal was officially inaugurated on July 27, 2007, by [Moroccan](/article/en/Morocco) King [Mohammed VI](/article/en/Mohammed_VI) following five years of construction and an investment of approximately two billion euros. The project's initial phase was constructed by a consortium including Møller-[Mærsk](/article/en/Mærsk), [Eurogate](/article/en/Eurogate), [Bouygues](/article/en/Bouygues), and Horizon Terminals. ### Expansion and Growth (2008–Present) Early performance exceeded projections: the port handled one million containers in 2008 and 1.22 million in 2009. In October 2008, a draft loan contract of $180 million was signed to fund expansion works for a second deepwater port facility, designated "Tanger Med II," to accommodate growing international container handling demand. Final official approval for Tanger Med II was received on January 7, 2009, with construction commencing on June 17, 2009. In November 2010, the [European Investment Bank](/article/en/European_Investment_Bank) (EIB) provided a €200 million loan to support the port's extension. Tanger Med II comprises two new container terminals (Terminals 3 and 4) with a combined additional capacity of 5 million containers. Terminal 3, with a capacity of 1 million TEU, began operations in January 2021, while Terminal 4, with a capacity of 5 million TEU, commenced operations in June 2019. These expansions elevated the total port capacity to 9–11 million containers. Cargo handling volumes demonstrated significant growth: the port processed 42.0 million tons in 2015, 65 million tons in 2019, 75 million tons in 2020, and 101 million tons in 2021. By 2024, approximately 162 million tons were being handled annually, with 9.6 million TEU containers processed in 2023. On January 4, 2024, Tanger Med ranked first in Africa according to a Business Insider Africa report. ## Geography and Location Tanger Med is situated at the locality of Oued Rmel in northern Morocco, where no significant port previously existed. The site was selected for its proximity to the [Iberian Peninsula](/article/en/Iberian_Peninsula), with the port of Tarifa being the nearest reference point at 15 km distance. The port's location within the [Strait of Gibraltar](/article/en/Strait_of_Gibraltar)—the world's second-busiest maritime route with approximately 100,000 vessel transits annually—provides strategic access to primary global shipping corridors. Goods reaching the port can reach [Marseille](/article/en/Marseille) or [Barcelona](/article/en/Barcelona) within 24 hours, or [Shanghai](/article/en/Shanghai) within 22 days. The port maintains connectivity with more than 180 ports across 70 countries. On the northeastern end of the port, adjacent to Montaña Kasbah, a large illuminated Arabic inscription welcomes sailors traveling eastbound through the Strait. The inscription reads "Allāh, Al-Waṭan, Al-Malīk" ("Allah, the Homeland, the King"), reflecting Morocco's national motto. The monument is visible from approximately 15 km away from Tarifa and can be located on satellite imagery at coordinates 35°53′58″N 5°28′57″W. ## Infrastructure and Facilities ### Port Complex Structure The Tanger Med port complex extends over approximately 1,000 hectares and comprises three operational ports: Tanger Med I, Tanger Med II, and the Passenger and Ro-Ro (Roll-on/Roll-off) Port. #### Container Terminals The port complex operates four container terminals with a combined capacity of 9 million TEU and approximately 3,600 linear meters of quay at depths of 15–18 meters: **Container Terminal 1 (TC1)**: Inaugurated in July 2007 with an investment of €150 million, operated by [APM Terminals](/article/en/APM_Terminals). Capacity: 1.5 million TEU; quay length: 800 meters; depth: 18 meters. **Container Terminal 2 (TC2)**: Opened in August 2008 with an investment of €150 million, operated by [Eurogate](/article/en/Eurogate). Capacity: 1.5 million TEU; quay length: 800 meters; depth: 15 meters. **Container Terminal 3 (TC3)**: Commenced operations in January 2021 with an investment of €240 million, operated by Tanger Alliance. Capacity: 1 million TEU; quay length: 800 meters. **Container Terminal 4 (TC4)**: Began operations in June 2019 with an investment of €1,100 million, operated by APM Terminals. Capacity: 5 million TEU; quay length: 2,000 meters. #### Passenger and Ro-Ro Port With an annual handling capacity of 7 million passengers, the facility includes eight berths with water depths of 8–12 meters, two border access and inspection zones, pre-boarding areas covering 8 hectares, and multimodal maritime infrastructure including bus and railway stations. The port maintains connections to six European cities and three countries ([Spain](/article/en/Spain), [France](/article/en/France), and [Italy](/article/en/Italy)). The facility is designed to accommodate vehicles with a nominal capacity of 700,000 TIR trucks, featuring an "Export Access" platform that processes approximately 2,100 units daily with an average transit time of 2 hours. #### Vehicle Terminals Two dedicated vehicle terminals with a combined storage capacity of 20 hectares process approximately 1 million new vehicles annually. The **Renault Vehicle Terminal (TVR)** spans 13 hectares and is connected by rail to the [Renault](/article/en/Renault) Mellousa manufacturing facility. The **Multi-User Vehicle Terminal (TVCU)** covers 7 hectares and accommodates other automakers, notably supporting exports from PSA Kenitra. #### Hydrocarbon Terminal Commissioned in February 2012 following a €160 million investment, the hydrocarbon terminal spans 12 hectares with storage capacity for 532,000 cubic meters of refined products distributed across 19 tanks. The facility processes 15 million tons of refined products annually (inbound and outbound) and provides trading, import, and bunker sales services. The terminal is integral to Morocco's petroleum product supply security. #### Bulk and General Cargo Terminal Operational since 2010, this 5-hectare facility handles import/export traffic supporting companies in the region's industrial and logistics zones, with a processing capacity of 800,000 tons of general cargo. A 450-meter quay supports bulk cargo operations. #### Rail Connections A dedicated rail line connects Tanger Med to major Moroccan cities, supporting transport of vehicles, hydrocarbons, and containers. The rail terminal occupies 10 hectares with three main tracks (800 meters in length) and additional sidings. ## Port Capacity and Performance ### Handling Capacity - **Containers**: 9,000,000 TEU annually - **Passengers**: 7,000,000 annually - **Vehicles**: 1,000,000 new vehicles annually - **TIR Trucks**: 700,000 annually - **Hydrocarbons**: 15,000,000 tons annually - **Solid Bulk**: 800,000 tons annually ### Actual Performance (2023) - **Containers**: 8.6 million TEU - **Passengers**: 2.7 million - **New Vehicles**: 578,446 - **TIR Trucks**: 477,993 - **Hydrocarbon Products**: 9,838,157 tons - **Solid Bulk**: 581,042 tons ### Historical Performance | Year | Cargo (Million Tons) | |------|---------------------| | 2015 | 42.0 | | 2019 | 65 | | 2020 | 75 | | 2021 | 101 | | 2023 | 162 | ## Governance and Administration Tanger Med is managed by the Agence Spéciale Tanger Méditerranée (TMSA), a public limited company established in 2003 to implement the government's strategic initiatives. The agency operates under an innovative governance model emphasizing cost control and management of the project's national impact. ### Supervisory Board The Supervisory Board comprises: - **Fouad Brini** – President of the Supervisory Board - **Abdelouafi Laftit** – Minister of the Interior - **Nadia Fettah El Alaoui** – Minister of Economy and Finance - **Nizar Baraka** – Minister of Equipment, Transport and Logistics - **Ryad Mezzour** – Minister of Industry and Trade - **Abdellatif Zaghnoun** – General Director of ANGSPE (representing the Moroccan State) - **Dounia Ben Abbas Taârji** – President of the Hassan II Fund for Economic and Social Development - **Khalid Safir** – General Director of the Deposit and Management Fund (CDG) - **Mounir El Bouyoussfi** – Director General of the Agency for the Promotion and Development of the North (APDN) ### Board of Directors and Executive Management The Board of Directors is composed of **Mehdi Tazi Riffi** (President) and board members including **Jaafar Mrhardy**, **Loubna Ghaleb**, and **Hassan Abkari**. In May 2025, the board of directors announced the dismissal of **Hassan Abkari**, who had served as general director since 2020. Abkari was required to liquidate a consulting firm he had founded in [Valencia](/article/en/Valencia,_Spain), Spain, in early 2025. The board subsequently appointed **Idriss El Arabi** as the new general director. ## Industrial Platform and Free Trade Zone ### Overview The industrial platform comprises an integrated free trade zone spanning over 3,000 hectares (with approximately 3,000 hectares developed as of 2023) and hosts more than 1,300 companies representing an annual business volume of €14 billion. The zone operates under the management of Tanger Med Zones, a subsidiary of the Tanger Med group, and the Free Trade Logistics Zone is operated by Medhub, another subsidiary. ### Activity Zones **Tanger Free Zone**: Launched in 1999 and developed across 440 hectares, this is the primary activity hub in northern Morocco, hosting companies in automotive, aerospace, electronics, and textile sectors. **Renault Tanger Med**: Launched in 2012 over 300 hectares, this facility hosts Africa's largest automobile manufacturing plant, with production capabilities supporting significant vehicle exports. **Tanger Automotive City**: Established in 2012 across 600 hectares, this zone serves as a center of excellence for integrated automotive activities, supporting a comprehensive automotive ecosystem. **Tétouan Shore**: Launched in 2013 across 90 hectares, dedicated to offshore services, Information Technology Outsourcing (ITO), Business Process Outsourcing (BPO), and Knowledge Process Outsourcing (KPO). **Tetouan Park**: Launched in 2015 across 156 hectares, serving as a relay for economic development in [Tétouan](/article/en/Tétouan), hosting industrial and logistics units targeting the northern Morocco regional market. **Mohammed VI Tanger Tech City**: A sustainable, integrated, and intelligent industrial city designed to receive industrial zones, service zones, residential complexes, and leisure facilities. As of 2023, 87 hectares are available for purchase, with a long-term total area of 2,167 hectares (including 1,220 hectares of residential area). **Fnideq Economic Activity Zone**: Exclusively dedicated to distribution and commercial activities, spanning 95 hectares, with an initial operational phase of 10 hectares hosting 76 warehouses. **Cabo Negro Commercial Zone**: Located near Cabo Negro, covering 70 hectares with an initial phase of 30 hectares completed. Created to support regional dynamics, tourism activities, and employment. ### Key Industrial Sectors and Companies Major multinational companies operating from Tanger Med include: - **Automotive**: [Renault](/article/en/Renault), [Nissan](/article/en/Nissan), [Fiat](/article/en/Fiat), [Delphi Automotive](/article/en/Delphi_Automotive), Sogefi, [Denso](/article/en/Denso), Magnetti Marelli, [Yazaki](/article/en/Yazaki), [Valeo](/article/en/Valeo) - **Electronics & Technology**: [Bosch](/article/en/Robert_Bosch_GmbH), [Huawei](/article/en/Huawei), [Siemens](/article/en/Siemens), [3M](/article/en/3M), [Furukawa Electric](/article/en/Furukawa_Electric) - **Retail & Logistics**: [Decathlon](/article/en/Decathlon_(retailer)), [Emirates Logistics Group](/article/en/Emirates_SkyCargo) (in partnership with [Adidas](/article/en/Adidas)), Daher The industrial platform represents sectors including automotive, aeronautics, food processing, logistics, and textiles. In 2017 alone, Tanger Med hosted 54 new industrial projects. ### Free Trade Logistics Zone Operational since late 2008 and integrated into the port, this 200-hectare zone specializes in value-added logistics activities including consolidation, distribution, and supply chain services at intercontinental scales. ## Rankings and Recognition ### International Port Rankings Tanger Med ranks **19th worldwide** among 500 container ports according to rankings published by Alphaliner in March 2024. The port is the leading port in Africa for the 7th consecutive year and the leading port in the Mediterranean for the 4th consecutive year. With 8.6 million TEU handled in 2023, Tanger Med surpassed prestigious ports including the [Port of New York](/article/en/Port_of_New_York_and_New_Jersey) (ranked 21st globally) and the [Port of Hamburg](/article/en/Port_of_Hamburg) (ranked 22nd). Among [European ports](/article/en/Ports_of_Europe), Tanger Med is surpassed only by the [Port of Rotterdam](/article/en/Port_of_Rotterdam) and the [Port of Antwerp-Bruges](/article/en/Port_of_Antwerp). Notably, Tanger Med is the only Mediterranean port to appear in the global top 30. In 2023, the port achieved the 2nd-best annual percentage performance within the global top 20, with a 13.4% increase, second only to [Qingdao](/article/en/Qingdao) (+16.9%). ### Economic Zone Recognition FDI Intelligence of the [Financial Times](/article/en/Financial_Times) ranked Tanger Med Zones as the **2nd global economic zone** in its 2020 "FDI's Global Free Zone of the Year" rankings, following the "Dubai Multi Commodities Center" in the [United Arab Emirates](/article/en/United_Arab_Emirates). This represented an improvement from its 5th-place ranking in 2019. ## Automotive Ecosystem Tanger Med has developed as a major automotive manufacturing and export hub. The [Renault](/article/en/Renault) TangerMed plant represents the largest automobile manufacturing facility in Africa. The port serves as the primary export gateway for vehicles produced at the Renault Mellousa factory and supports operations for major automotive suppliers including Nissan, Fiat, Delphi, Sogefi, Denso, Magnetti Marelli, Yazaki, and Valeo, creating an integrated automotive ecosystem. ## Strategic Significance ### Geographic Advantage Tanger Med's position at the intersection of the [Atlantic Ocean](/article/en/Atlantic_Ocean) and [Mediterranean Sea](/article/en/Mediterranean_Sea) and on the [Strait of Gibraltar](/article/en/Strait_of_Gibraltar) provides strategic advantages for transshipment operations. The port serves as a major hub for container transshipment and is the leading facility for cereal transshipment in the northwestern African region—a function previously non-existent in the area. ### European Integration The port's proximity to the [European Union](/article/en/European_Union) (15 km from Spanish territory) positions it to serve as a gateway for Morocco's exports and a distribution hub for European goods entering North African markets. This strategic position supports Morocco's orientation toward export-based economic development and the implementation of its free trade agreement with the EU. ### Container Transshipment Tanger Med has captured a significant portion of the growing container transshipment market, competing directly with the [Port of Algeciras](/article/en/Port_of_Algeciras) for traffic between Europe, North Africa, the Mediterranean, and the Persian Gulf toward North America. ## Geopolitical Context In 2022, [The New York Times](/article/en/The_New_York_Times) reported that [Russia](/article/en/Russia) has utilized Tanger Med to circumvent trade restrictions imposed following the invasion of [Ukraine](/article/en/Invasion_of_Ukraine_(2022)). This development illustrates the port's role in global supply chains and its strategic importance beyond regional commerce. ## Related Infrastructure Tanger Med integrates with broader transportation networks through: - **Highway connections** linking the port to major Moroccan cities and European routes - **Railway connections** serving container, vehicle, and passenger transport - **Multimodal terminal facilities** enabling seamless cargo transfer between maritime, rail, and road modes ## Competition The primary regional competitor is the [Port of Algeciras](/article/en/Port_of_Algeciras) in Spain, located on the opposite side of the [Strait of Gibraltar](/article/en/Strait_of_Gibraltar). Both ports compete for cargo handling between Europe and North Africa and the Mediterranean region as well as traffic to states along the Persian Gulf directed toward [North America](/article/en/North_America). ## See Also - [Moroccan Ports](/article/en/Ports_of_Morocco) - [Economy of Morocco](/article/en/Economy_of_Morocco) - [Economy of Tangier](/article/en/Tangier) - [Strait of Gibraltar](/article/en/Strait_of_Gibraltar) - [Port of Algeciras](/article/en/Port_of_Algeciras) - [Automotive Industry in Morocco](/article/en/Automotive_industry) - [Free Trade Zones](/article/en/Special_economic_zone) - [Mediterranean Ports](/article/en/List_of_ports_of_the_Mediterranean) ## References ### External Links - Official Tanger Med Website - Tanger Mediterranean Special Agency (TMSA) - Marsa Maroc Network (subsidiary managing 24 container and bulk terminals across 10 Moroccan ports) - Tanger Med Zones - Medhub Free Trade Logistics Zone --- **Note**: Information synthesized from English, Arabic, German, Spanish, and French Wikipedia editions. Some variations in capacity figures reflect different reporting periods and methodologies across sources. Performance data primarily reflects the most recent available statistics (2023–2024).
